title: Potteric Carr Nature Reserve Walking Route

images.title: Steve F, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The café and visitor centre. Set in the middle of the reserve and a fair walk from the car park.

images.title: Dave Dunford / Mother Drain, Potteric Carr
images.caption: Mother Drain. Much work is going on on the Potteric Carr Nature Reserve, and presumably a bridge is planned here.

images.title: Dave Dunford / Potteric Carr
images.caption: The wetlands area after heavy rain.

images.title: Dave Dunford / Huxter Well Drain
images.caption: Huxter Well Drain. With brick barn adjacent, close to the M18 motorway and the Nature Reserve.

images.title: Dave Taylor / Black Carr Bridge
images.caption: Black Carr Bridge. Girder bridge carrying the railway over the Potteric Carr yellow route nature trail and East Coast Mainline railway.

images.title: Dave Taylor / Red Route
images.caption: Red Route path along the former trackbed of the Dearne Valley Railway

images.title: Steve F, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bridleway bridge over The Mother Drain

description: Follow a network of footpaths around this large nature reserve in Doncaster. There are nearly 500 acres to explore with habitats including marsh, scrub, waterways, grassland and woodland. Over 230 species of bird have been spotted in the reserve including Bittern, Greater Spotted Woodpecker and Kingfisher. Also look out for other wildlife including Roe Deer and Grass Snakes. There is an abundance of interesting plantlife in the reserve too. Yellow iris and pink violets can be seen near the waterways while hawthorn blossom lines the pathways. The reserve also has very good on site facilities including a Visitor centre and cafe. It is located less than 2 miles south of the centre of Doncaster.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Head a few miles north from the reserve and you'll find some nice woodland trails around Sandall Beat Wood. You could also pick up the Doncaster River Walk and visit the picturesque Sprotbrough Falls and the impressive Conisbrough Viaduct. The long distance Trans Pennine Trail and Doncastrian Way can also be picked up here. To the east you can pick up the Peatlands Way to explore Thorne Moors and Hatfield Moors, part of the Humberhead Peatlands National Nature Reserve. The moors are the second largest lowland raised peat bog in England and notable for their diversity of wildlife and plantlife.

display_address: Carolina Way, Lakeside, Doncaster, South Yorkshire, England, DN4 5PN, United Kingdom
